p: The study was conducted in the Simpson Desert, central Australia ( figure 1). This region occupies 170 000 km 2; dune fields comprise 73% of the region, with smaller areas consisting of clay pans, rocky outcrops and gibber flats [ 34]. The sand dunes run parallel in a north–south direction aligned with the prevailing southerly wind. The dunes are up to 10 m high and 0.6–1 km apart [ 35]. Vegetation in the interdune swales and on dune sides is predominantly spinifex grassland ( Triodia basedowii) with patchy cover of small stands of gidgee trees ( Acacia georginae) and other woody Acacia shrubs or mallee eucalypts; low-lying clay pans fill with water temporarily after heavy rain [ 33].
